YANG DI-PERTUAN NEGARA'S SPEECH

(Debate on the Address)
(Sixth Day)


    Order read for resumption of adjourned debate on Question [9th August, 1960],

    `That the following Address in reply to the speech of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara be agreed to:-

    "We, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Singapore, express our thanks to the Yang di-Pertuan Negara for the speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the present session of this Assembly.".'-(The Prime Minister).

    Question again proposed.

2.31 p.m.

    Inche Buang Bin Omar Junid (Kallang)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I will continue with the speech which I started yesterday.

    On the first day of this debate, the Member for Hong Lim accused the Government of failing to implement democratic practices. Before the Member for Hong Lim introduced his 16

Column: 472

resolutions into this House, I personally know that these 16 resolutions brought up by the Hong Lim Branch were read out by the hon. Member at our Party Conference. The resolutions were rejected. Subsequently the hon. Member again raised the issue of the 16 resolutions at the Badminton Hall rally where he made accusations against the Government. At the same time, he boasted that he was the real fighter for the detainees and for the interest of the trade union movement in Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am really amused at the antics of the Member for Hong Lim. If he is so very much concerned about the deregistration of the four unions and the detainees. I would like him to answer this question: when did he start to fight for the welfare of the detainees and the trade union movement? Has he ever undergone the hardships experienced by the trade union movement? Has he ever gone through the experience of being detained? Anybody can give the answer, Mr Speaker - that he has not experienced all that. This is an attempt on his part to gain power for his own ends, by hoodwinking the people of Singapore. I know full well, Mr Speaker, Sir, about the circumstances relating to the deregistration of the unions, the trade union movement in Singapore as a whole, and the position of the detainees, as I have been personally detained on two occasions in the past. The Singapore Trades Union Congress interviewed the Minister for Labour and Law and exchanged views on the four deregistered unions, after which they were satisfied. Before the Member for Hong Lim raised this issue, we from the S.T.U.C. and the other unions had already submitted our views to the Minister for Labour and Law. But the Member for Hong Lim - Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not want to use unparliamentary words as I may be asked to sit down - might have borrowed or stolen the views of other trade unions. I still remember a story told to me when I was at school about Sang Kanchil and a heron. Sang Kanchil is very intelligent and wily and can outwit all the other animals. But all the same, he has one weakness - his insincerity.

Column: 473

Although he is wily, he is insincere. Tigers, elephants and crocodiles can be outwitted by the wiliness of Sang Kanchil. The story goes like this. One day, he asked a heron to cross a river on a river crate with him with the thought of outwitting the heron. When Sam Kanchil felt sure that he could manage to get across safely to the other side, he caused the river crate to sink. The result was that Sang Kanchil was drowned but the heron was able to fly to safety. This is analogous to an insincere man who will ultimately drown himself. I hope that the labour movement and the people of Singapore will not be confused by the 16 resolutions. We must be on guard against any action initiated by the Member for Hong Lim.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would also like to refer to the speech of the Member for Aljunied. I was shocked to hear the blind accusations of the hon. Member against the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development. He accused the Parliamentary Secretary of trying to win over the constituents of the Southern Islands so that he would be successful as a candidate for that ward in the next general elections. Sir, this is like the story I related just now about Sang Kanchil. The members of the P.A.P. do not go about their work with a view to offering themselves as candidates in the next general elections. This is a false and nonsensical accusation calculated to confuse the people. Can the Member for Aljunied substantiate his accusation that the Parliamentary Secretary invited the peng-hulus of the Southern Islands and told them that it was his intention to stand as a candidate for that ward in the coming general elections? If he cannot substantiate his accusation, then it is false. Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the hon. Member has run out of ideas to further confuse the minds of the people of Singapore.

    The People's Action Party will constantly be on the look-out against any activities initiated by the Member for Hong Lim and the Member for Aljunied. We will continue to oppose insincere leaders in the interest of the people as a whole.

Column: 474



2.41 p.m.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong (Jalan Kayu)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, for the past few days, I have been listening to the speeches of Members of the Opposition. All of these speeches are feats of acrobatics showing purposeful abstruseness, distortion of Government's policies and the creation of disharmony. Since the formation of our Party, we have never deviated from our consistent stand. We have been expressing our independent character and have never been controlled by others. Before the general election, the P.A.P. had told the people that it was non-Communist. We did not conceal our policies and we have been trustworthy. During the general election, we were also telling the people that we were non-Communist in order to win over the people. The situation in Singapore has been fundamentally secure since the P.A.P. took over the government after its victory in the election 14 months ago. This fact shows that the P.A.P. policies are successful and right. The former Chief Minister. Mr Lim Yew Hock has not remembered this fact and does not absorb our experience. On the contrary, he still wants to go back to the road of anti-people and pro-colonialism. He has been very stubborn and has not reflected on the lesson of the failure of his S.P.A. even up to the present moment. Now, the Member for Cairnhill wants to pull us into the water and make us go along his old road of failure. Since we have expressed our non-Communist attitude, we will never change it, no matter what misleading and challenging words we may encounter from the Opposition Members. Our present task is to seek the welfare of the people and serve them in a better way.

    The Member for Cairnhill has become very belligerent and challenges us to a light in the by-elections. The people are not interested in this and it is, in fact, wasting people's resources and energy. We will not be so childish as to do this. I would like to ask the Member for Cairnhill why does he want to drag us into the water and what is his motive in wanting us to be anti-Communist? He

Column: 475

wants to have an effortless gain by making us fail in our pledge by betraying the people and creating disorder. Is this not a naive fancy of his? Mr Speaker, the Member for Cairnhill talks a lot about anti-Communism, and is very much interested because he wants to become a hero of the anti-Communist movement in Singapore, thereby earning another title for that, like the one he has received from the Federation of Malaya. Even if he should obtain a title for being a hero of the anti-Communist movement, would it benefit the welfare of the people and solve the unemployment problem? Could he achieve results by being just anti-Communist? What the people, both the Chinese and English-educated, are greatly concerned is whether there is security of livelihood and the possibility of solving the unemployment problem, and not merely the question of whether the State is anti-Communist or pro-Communist. The road that the Government is taking is the most practical road, that is, to find out ways and means to create situations for the purpose of solving the unemployment problem and to look after the livelihood of the people. This is a practical and effective way of checking the development of pro-Communist activity.

    Mr Speaker, the speech of the Member for Cairnhill is lengthy, but it has not expressed any anti-colonial feelings at all. Many of my colleagues have clarified that we are not tools of either the colonialists or the Communists, and I doubt whether the Member for Cairnhill himself is a tool of the colonialists.

    Mr Speaker, after hearing the speeches of the Members of the Opposition, I am of the opinion that they have not contributed any constructive criticisms of Government's policies. An Opposition Member's responsibility is to speak for the people and to make useful suggestions to raise the standard of living and welfare of the people, and not simply to oppose this and oppose that. Members of the Opposition have not done this. For the past few days, their lengthy speeches are misleading, and their purpose is to make political capital

Column: 476

out of them. They have not even suggested how the basic problems may be solved. For example, a few days ago, the Member for Joo Chiat said that he had reared chickens. Does he mean to say that, by having reared chickens, he is a qualified farmer and understands the hardship of the farmers? Deceiving people by this means does not amount to an expression of concern for the farmers. In fact, the farmers already know how to increase their production. The problem is how best to market their products. This is also a problem of rural economy, and a problem relating to land. He did not mention all this. So, let me remind him that without going to the farmers and without knowing their hardship, one cannot serve the farmers. The Member for Joo Chiat said that Japanese hens and leghorns can lay about 240 to 280 eggs per year. The Deputy Prime Minister has touched on this. But I would like to point out his childish, political cheating -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think I heard the expression "childish, political cheating". If that is so, then, of course, that is an expression which should not be used. Perhaps the hon. Member can assure me that that was not the expression he used. If it is the expression he used, then he must withdraw that expression.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): I think, Mr Speaker, just now I was -

    Mr Speaker: Order. Can I have a reply? If the expression "childish, political cheating" was used, then it has to be withdrawn. If it was not used, then the hon. Member can tell me that it was not the expression used.

    Mr Tan Cheng Tong(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I withdraw the words "childish, political cheating".

    As a matter of fact, the farmers have reared these two breeds of chicken. Because the local climate is different, these hens cannot lay as many eggs as the Member for Joo Chiat claimed. The egg production is, what the Deputy Prime Minister has said, about 260 a year.

Column: 477



    I would point out here that the Deputy Prime Minister's speech is based on facts taken from books. We must know that in Australia and Japan. the climate is different from ours, and this yield of egg production is possible. But over here, because of our climate, we cannot expect the same results.

    The Prime Minister has said that the Opposition Members are weak in their judgment. The correctness of the Prime Minister's judgment can be proved here by all these facts.

2.56 p.m.

    The Minister for Health (Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, at the Assembly sitting a few days ago the Member for Tanglin, among other things, complained like a babbling old man that too much time had been wasted in this Assembly in debating the internal matters of the People's Action Party. Besides that, the hon. Member also complained that the analysis of the political situation in Singapore, as presented in the speech of the Prime Minister the other day, confused him and that he did not understand the analysis. Sir, in fact, the Member for Tanglin said that he wanted to know the significance of that part of the Prime Minister's speech which reads [Hansard, 3rd August, 1960, col. 64]:

    `What is the worst that can happen in the immediate future for us as a Government? it is that the Government may find itself out-maneuvered and out-propagandaed by these Left-wing adventurers, in which case the P.A.P. will have to take the count in this fight, and the Communists will be counted out for many years to come.'

It would appear that he did not comprehend the meaning of that statement of the Prime Minister, that it is the business of the Government to ensure that if a collision is to take place between these Left-wing adventurers and the colonialists-imperialists, the P.A.P. should let them break their heads on each other.

    I am fully convinced that the Member for Tanglin did not understand and was confused about such matters, because his inability to comprehend has already become chronic, and the reason

Column: 478

is not difficult to seek. His whole intellectual approach operates on the old wave-length, which means it cannot receive messages about happenings in our country which are being sent on a new wave-length. His approach to our problems still clings on along political lines of the pre-Rendel and Progressive Party era. It is too well known that during those years political questions were decided by tete-a-tetes with the colonial governors and at cocktail parties.

    The Member for Tanglin ought to realise that times have changed. We have moved on to an age of mass politics. The social forces which decide political problems now move and act in ways which are no longer similar to those found in the pre-Rendel years. Mr Speaker, Sir, for example, the attitude of the Member for Tanglin to political parties is typical of the approach of politicians in that age. The pre-Rendel political parties, as exemplified by the Progressive Party, the Democratic Party, later the Liberal-Socialist Party, and the Labour Front have no roots in the people. The leaders of those political parties did not reflect major political forces. As such, splits and dissensions within those parties had little or no impact on the political life outside their own ranks. The P.A.P. on the other hand, because of its deeper roots in the political life of the people, therefore mirrors the line up of political forces as they really exist in Singapore. It is clear that the Ong Eng Guan affair is important and merits attention in so far as it provides an opportunity for forces which have been referred to as Left-wing adventurers to challenge the non-communist socialist approach of the P.A.P. Government.

    Mr Speaker, allow me to give a more frank elucidation. The line-up of forces in this Assembly does not actually mirror the political forces in this country. The decisive political manoeuvres are taken either on this side of the House or outside the Assembly. The alternative force to the P.A.P. cannot be found in any of the political parties or individuals represented on that side of the House.

Column: 479



    Mr Speaker, this claim is not arrogance on our part. It is a statement of fact. Perhaps by now Members of the Opposition are able to see that the Prime Minister's analysis when he opened the debate on the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's policy statement itself shows that both the actions and speeches of Government are designed primarily to influence and manoeuvre against political forces outside this Assembly. In this Assembly yesterday, it appeared to me that the Member for Joo Chiat, who had maintained a self-imposed silence for the last 14 months, and who had himself claimed that he had not been deaf nor blind during that period, had admitted that there is no alternative to the P.A.P. at present. But, of course, it does not matter two hoots to us even if the Member for Tanglin and others do not make this admission, because the actions of the People's Action Party are based on facts and the truth regardless of whether other people admit them or not.

    Mr Speaker, if the opposition forces we have to contend with are the opposition Members, then our task would be a very simple one indeed. Unfortunately, the position today is not so. I have explained about the position of the S.P.A. members and the Member for Hong Lim can only be looked upon as a puppet being used to further the ends of the people outside this Assembly.

    It should be clear to everybody that the issue before us is whether or not non-Communist socialism can succeed in our country. If the non-Communist socialist system based on parliamentary democracy fails, then the alternatives are either a resurgence of colonialism or a resurgence of rebellious violence. I trust the whole Opposition will understand what I have said.

    Mr Speaker, the other day, the Member for the Southern Islands touched on the question of merger. My apologies here. It seems that he does not understand that the communal problem, the problem of uniting the various races into one strong united Malayan nation, is a problem which not only must be faced

Column: 480

and solved by the Singapore Government alone. The truth is that that problem is similarly faced by the Federation Government also. The Alliance Government in the Federation of Malaya is busying itself with various ways and means so that non-Malays, which number almost 50 per cent there, will show their undivided loyalty towards this country. Briefly, if the communal problem can be solved slowly in the Federation, it follows that the communal problem in Singapore will follow suit. In fact, in as much as the Federation Government is constantly anxious and vigilant, I repeat - is constantly anxious and vigilant in regard to the doings of Malay or non-Malay communalists over there, the P.A.P. Government in Singapore is, no less vigilant and alert towards all types of communalists and Chauvinists in Singapore.

    When a dedicated and revolutionary Government comes into power at the close of a colonial era, we must all, including the honourable Members of the Opposition, expect to find drastic alterations taking place to change the emphasis of the services provided for the people, and also the speed at which old ways are to give place to new. As an honest Government, the P.A.P. has already admitted, in the Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech, that errors and mistakes took place as a result of our early zeal. But it would be wrong to let our self-admitted mistakes entirely overshadow the very real advantages of the swift moving changes and policies in our first year of office. A feature of that first year has been the time given over to planning. I am sure Members of the Opposition must agree that any sensible Government should plan, and that the effective implementation of Government policies for the good of the people as a whole are only likely to yield good results if based on careful thinking and careful planning right from the blueprint stage.

    I would now like to indicate some of the achievements of the first year as they affect my Ministry.

    The change of emphasis from the curative to the preventive aspects has taken place in several ways. Legislation

Column: 481

for compulsory immunisation against Diphtheria and the compulsory vaccination of school children against Tuberculosis will help to spread an awareness of the need to control these diseases among the younger population. Immunisation among very small children through Maternity and Child Health Clinics was stepped up against Diphtheria. Whooping Cough, Tetanus, Small-Pox, and T.B. In spite of rapid changes, the Ministry managed to do 30,000 Diphtheria immunisation and 60,000 B.C.G. vaccinations during the year. In addition, Mr Speaker, some 60,000 Tuberculin tests were made as the voluntary campaign among primary school children was intensified. I am sure we are all glad that the absence of the so-called tropical diseases has continued during the year and that Singapore is free from Cholera, Plague, Yellow Fever anti Malaria.

    Ante-natal and post-natal services were intensified in 25 Maternal and Child Health Clinics, 22 Visiting Centres and 8 Village Midwifery Centres. Of these, some 28 are in the rural areas and we shall continue to encourage home confinements among the city and rural population.

    As regards Mass Health Education Campaigns, we all know that a Blood Donation campaign organised by the Ministry registered 6,000 donors out of which 2,500 have already donated blood. Studies were made for the implementation of a Family Planning Campaign and plans are well advanced to stimulate intelligent planned parenthood among the adult population. During the past year plans for a Mass Health Education Campaign to cover nutrition, maternal and infant care have been completed and these should be implemented within a reasonable period of time.

    Members may be glad to hear of our efforts to eliminate obvious inadequacies existing in the Health Services. Integration of Government, City Council and Rural Board Services has reached an advanced stage. The Thomson Road Hospital now operates as a general hospital for acute cases, and it is only a matter of time before the whole hospital

Column: 482

is fully functioning in the service of the people. Two new Out-patient Clinics have been prepared at Jalan Kayu and Lim Ah Pin Road, and both will help in relieving the pressure eventually on the Out-patient Service in the General Hospital. In changing the functions of the Thomson Road Hospital, we have not forgotten the chronic sick. The renovation of four blocks at Wood-bridge Hospital to house this unfortunate category of the sick has been completed.

    I do not need to remind Members that TB, is still our greatest scourge. The Report of a Pilot Survey conducted under the Colombo Plan, was completed in 1959 and set the incidence at 3.7 per cent of the population in this country. On my instructions, a Committee enquired into the incidence of T.B. among industrial occupations. Unfortunately, the Committee was unable to relate specifically the incidence of the disease to particular occupations, but the Committee's labours have indicated what kind of data is lacking before preventive measures can be devised. We are now making arrangements for the necessary data to be obtained in a Mass X-ray Campaign planned for the end of this year. I have already mentioned legislation to compel the vaccination of our children. Members will be glad to know that every baby born in the Kandang Kerbau Maternity Hospital is vaccinated with B.C.G. as soon as possible after birth, provided the parent agrees.

    Ample opportunities for staff training were offered during the year and the courses selected for training will help raise the standard of our Medical Services and also assist our talented staff to obtain higher qualifications of a world standard.

    By example, precept and instruction, we have sought to ensure that kindness, courtesy and consideration to patients and the public is given in all hospitals and provided at all Out-patient Clinics.

    The Yang di-Pertuan Negara's speech has mentioned our efforts to recruit Chinese and Malay educated persons into the Nursing and Midwifery Services. This policy will be continued.

Column: 483



    My Parliamentary Secretary has given an indication that we will make efforts to recruit doctors from overseas.

    In this connection let me quote from the P.A.P. Election Manifesto. We said last year:

    `It cannot be denied that in Singapore the medical situation leaves room for improvement. There are six Government hospitals, 650 doctors, of whom 350 are private practitioners. The ratio of population to doctors is about 2,300 persons per doctor. This compares unfavourably with Japan, as well as with advanced western countries. With the rapid increase in population special steps would be taken to increase the output of doctors in the next few years...'

and again:

    `The number of doctors produced each year by the University of Malaya is not sufficient to sustain the rates of expansion envisaged in our programme. As will be seen, a large number of doctors will be required to staff the district hospitals, a chronic hospital and a network of people's clinics. Accordingly, it will be necessary to import doctors from abroad and from available information, the best sources of recruitment would be Western Germany, Japan, India and Hong Kong.'

    As Members have been informed, we have had negotiations with the representative of the Japanese Government and as a result, we shall have available, at our service, 27 Japanese doctors. These Japanese doctors shall be on two years contract to the Government of Singapore; their passage fares to and from Japan shall be met by the Japanese Government.

    It is expected that those doctors shall be made available for service in Singapore before the end of the year.

    I would also like to announce that the Singapore Government has been in close consultation with the Government of Israel with a view to enlisting their assistance in order to improve the Health Services in Singapore. The Government of Israel has expressed its willingness to assist us in the supply of Specialists, and has also offered two or three places in the Hebrew College of Medicine for Singapore citizens wishing to take up undergraduate courses. Two Israeli Professors, Prof. Moshe Rachmilewitz, Prof. of Medicine, Dean of the

Column: 484

Hebrew University, and Prof. Prywes, Associate Dean of the Hebrew University, are now in Singapore for a two-week stay to appraise for themselves the medical facilities available in Singapore prior to the Government of Israel sending their specialists to work here.

    The Government of Israel has also stated that it would like to send out a Medical Research Unit to work in collaboration both with the Government of Singapore and the University of Malaya. The University of Malaya has expressed its desire to co-operate with the Medical Team that the Government of Israel wishes to send out.

    The Ministry of Health has also received applications from medical officers from India, Ceylon and other Commonwealth countries. These applications are being considered and it is hoped that by the end of the year at least twenty Medical Officers shall be recruited from Commonwealth countries.

    With this recruitment the present pressure of work upon our doctors would be considerably relieved and a far higher standard of patient-care would be achieved. In addition, the recruitment of doctors from overseas countries would enable the Ministry to proceed with the expansion of the health services, i.e. the full occupation of Thomson Road Hospital, the occupation of eight vacant wards at Tan Tock Seng Hospital, and the occupation of the new Gynaecological Block at Kandang Kerbau Maternity Hospital.

    In addition, the presence of doctors from overseas will enable the Government of Singapore to release more local doctors for post-graduate studies. More scholarships will be provided for local doctors for such studies.

    At present, there are 25 local doctors on post-graduate study courses in the United Kingdom and Australia. It is my intention to provide every facility for local doctors to proceed overseas for post-graduate study.

    The Ministry of Health is giving close attention to its development projects and the planning out of its staff training programme. It can be expected that the

Column: 485

standard of medical care in the State would be considerably improved by about the middle of next year.

    I have limited myself to the cold hard facts of planning and achievements during the course of the year. Let these speak for themselves as our efforts in the coming year will, I am confident, speak for themselves.

    Mr Speaker, I now come to the accusation that has been levelled against the Government by the Member for Cairnhill. I fail to understand the Member for Cairnhill. He has misled this House and attempted to mislead the public by saying that the Parliamentary Secretary has ridiculed the conferment of the honour and title "Tun". I have been closely following the speeches of Members. It might be that he was basing his speech on rumours outside. I would like to deny categorically here the accusation made by the Member for Cairnhill, because there was not a single Member from the Government side who had derided the honours and titles of the Federation Government. I know it was only the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development who spoke in reply to the Member for Kampong Kembangan, that if the Prime Minister had declared his unequivocal stand as a non-Communist, he might have been conferred a title as had been conferred on the ex-Chief Minister. This was the statement made in this Assembly. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development has clearly reiterated our non-Communist stand. He has also explained that every fighter in the struggle for freedom does not hope to receive or seek honours and titles from the sky. It is hoped that the fruits of our struggle will be of benefit to the people as a whole.

    Another point, Mr Speaker, I was surprised to hear the Member for Aljunied when he read his speech like a schoolboy and defended his colleague, the Member for Hong Lim. The programme for the Southern Islands was initiated by the man whose name has been mentioned in this Assembly, that is, Mr Meadows. Then the Member for

Column: 486

Aljunied went on to show the sincerity of the Member for Hong Lim who is said to have allocated $200,000 for the development of the Southern Islands, which is now being looked after by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development. I would like to say that at the beginning of this year the Parliamentary Secretary offered the services of two graduates of the University of Malaya to carry out investigations in a voluntary capacity and to draw up a scheme in order to assist the fishermen of the Southern Islands. What did the Member for Hong Lim, who was the Minister for National Development, say at that time? He rejected the offer with the excuse that there was no money and that the sum allocated was not for the Southern Islands. In April this year, Mr Speaker, it was only after this matter had been discussed at the Executive Committee meeting of the P.A.P. that the Minister agreed to set aside the sum of $200,000 which was mentioned by the Member for Aljunied. He is not in the Executive Committee. Therefore, he does not know what he is talking about and he only mouths whatever is fed to him. A scheme to help Malay fishermen by way of giving them she-goats has already been submitted to the acting Minister for National Development, as was mentioned in the speech of the Deputy Prime Minister yesterday. I am really sorry for the Member for Kampong Kembangan and the Member for Geylang Serai on account of their short-sighted view on the subject of culture.
